item.title: Code Tidying: The Story of a Backseat Driver
item.description: Let’s embark on a thought experiment. Envision yourself as a driving virtuoso, conquering city streets with gear shifts smoother than a buttered dolphin on a rainbow.

item.title: Four Lenses of Productivity: Incubyte's Take
item.description: This blog discusses different levels of productivity along with common pitfalls and different ways to optimize them.

item.title: The Compounding Effect of Tidying Using CodeScene
item.description: It turns out that most of a developer’s tasks end up being tactical activities, such as adding a text box here, adding a checkbox there, fixing a bug, or working with an outage.

item.title: Psychological Safety in Agile Teams
item.description: Think back to the first time your code was under review.

item.title: Is there a more economical and efficient alternative to Salesforce?
item.description: Choosing a direction when redefining your organization’s technical backbone is never easy.

item.title: Accelerate: Metrics that Define High-Performance Software Delivery
item.description: Accelerate by Nicole Forsgren, Jez Humble, and Gene Kim was released in 2018, and it changed how I think about software delivery.

item.description: I recently came across Simple Sabotage Field Manual. What struck me was you do not need bombs and explosives to start sabotaging.

item.title: 12 Books Developers Must Read
item.description: Books are a massive source of knowledge. Before we list all the books here, we want to discuss why we think it’s essential for programmers to read them.

item.title: Benefits and Challenges of Open-Source Development
item.description: Open-source software (OSS) is the holy grail for developers. It is a hub of innovation through intense collaboration in this era of agile software development.

item.title: Do not assume that technical debt is a problem with your code

item.title: Not All Tests are the Same
item.description: On multiple occasions, I have worked on projects where I learned how critical testing is and that not all tests are the same.

item.title: Do not Release Code Without Automated Tests
item.description: Most projects that I see facing serious problems lack tests. You should write tests for two things

item.title: Do not Get so busy that you stop learning
item.description: Learning is the most vital part of a software developer’s life.

item.title: Do not Optimize Prematurely
item.description: Once again, you would think that the software development community has moved past this point, but I still get many teammates who want to “save memory” using HashMaps instead of POJOs.

item.title: Do not Show Separate Estimate for Unit Testing
item.description: Once I was asked in an interview (I was the interviewer!

item.title: Do not Copy and paste code to minimize the impact:
item.description: Have you ever seen code in your module, which was so complex that you decided to copy and paste it entirely rather than changing it to accommodate your requirement?

item.title: Do not Fall for faux agile
item.description: Enough ink is already spilled on this topic, nevertheless talking about it once again may not hurt.
